Despatches from United States Consuls in Sierra Leone, 1858-1906 T-438

div1.p: Commercial Agency of the United States of America at Sierra Leone 7th Jany 1871
Sir,

I have the honor to report for the information of the Department of State that the Schooner "Nettle" of 31 tons Register of New York Arrived at this port on the 23rd December 1870 with a general Cargo Consisting of Among other articles 4,000 lbs of Powder and according to the Regulations of this Port proceeded to the Powder ground for the purpose of depositing the same in the Magazine before coming into harbour. Upon the following morning I was informed
Honourable Hamilton Fish
Secretary of State
Washington D.C.
informed by the Customs Authority that it was their duty to seize her in conformity with an Act of the Privy Council dated 13th February 1849 which was accordingly done. I have the honor to enclose a copy of the Act under which she was seized together with copies of the correspondence relating to the matter and respectfully request you will be pleased to furnish me with Instructions as I have no Documentary evidence in the Consulate for any guidance Supposing a similar case should occur, also under what part of the International or other Law the Vessel was seized.
div1.fw:
I have the honor to be
Sir
Your most obt Servant
J.B. Upton
U.S. Commercial Agent
pro tem
div1.ab: Commercial Agency of the United States of America at Sierra Leone
Relative to seizure of America Schr "Nettle"

div1.p:
Commercial Agency of the United States of America at Sierra Leone
December 27th 1870
Sir,

I have the honor to request that you will please place before His Excellency the Governor-in-chief the following remarks in regard to the American Schooner "Kettle" to my consignment now under detention in consequence of a violation of the Acts of 13th February 1849.
The "Nettle" is of 32 tons register has a cargo consisting of 600 Kegs of Powder besides some clothing and Provisions.
Arriving on the 23rd inst proceeded at once to the Powder ground where she still remains in charge of the Custom Authorities.

The Owner of the Vessel and Cargo Mr. Edward C. Mosser is also on board, who assures me that untill now, both he and the Master were quite ignorant of the existence of such an Act.
Hon: J. J. Kendall
Colonial Secreatry
&c &c
I have besides consulted several of the Principal Merchants of this place and they as well as myself were also in perfect ignorance of such a regulation.
I therefore most respectfully request that His Excellency will take as lenient a view of this case as possible.

I have the honor to be
Sir
Your Obedient Servant
J.B. Upton
U.S. Commercial Agent
pro tem

Colonial Office Sierra Leone
28th December 1870
Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No 24 of the 27th instant respecting the detention of the of the American Schooner "Nettle" by the Collector of Customs, in consequence of a violation of the order in Council of 13th February 1849.

Having laid the same before His Excellency The Governor-in-Chief, I am directed to inform you that His Excellency does not think it necessary to direct any proceeding in the matter, and the Collector has therefore been instructed to liberate the vessel, on payment of any expenses which have been incurred.

I have the honor to be
Sir
Your Most Obt Servant
(sgd) J. J. Kendall
Colonial Secretary
div1.fw: J. B. Upton Esquire U.S. Commercial Agent

div1.p: At the Court at Buckingham Palace. the 13th day of February 1849

Present
The Queens most Excellent Majesty in Council
A Table of Prohibitions and Restrictions

Gun Powder, Arms, Ammunition, or utensils of war prohibited to be imported to be used therein, except from the United Kingdom, or from some other British possession, but such articles may, nevertheless, be imported in any Vessel which may legally trade with the British possession on the western Coast of Africa, for the purpose of being warehoused at the Port of Freetown for exportation only

And if any goods shall be imported or brought into the said Colony contrary to any of the prohibitions or restrictions mentioned in such table in respect of such goods, the same shall be forfeited; and if the ship or vessel in which such goods shall be imported be of less burthen than sixty tons, such ship or vessel shall be forfeited.

I certify the above to be a true copy.
J.B. Upton

Commercial Agency of the United States of America at Sierra Leone
28th December 1870
Sir,

I am in receipt of a Communication from the Honourable J. J. Kendall Colonial Secretary informing me that instructions had been issued for the release of the American Sch: "Nettle" upon payment of the expenses incurred.
I respectfully request to be furnished with the amount of those expenses to enable me to enter the Vessel. Payment of which I hold myself responsible.

I am Sir,
Your Obt Servant
(sgde) J. B. Upton
U.S. Coml Agent
Pro tem
& Consignee
div1.fw:
John Shaw Esq
Collector of Customs

div1.p: Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter No 26 of this days date requesting to be furnished with the amount of the expense incurred by the American Schooner "Nettle" and beg to inform you that 20/- is the amount due by that vessel to this date.

I am Sir
Your Obdt Servant
(sgd) John Shaw
Collector of Customs
